children.value: Queries are the methods that Testing Library gives you to find elements on the page. There are several

("get", "find", "query"); the difference between them is whether the query will throw an error if no element is found or if it will return a Promise and retry. Depending on what page content you are selecting, different queries may be more or less appropriate. See the
for recommendations on how to make use of semantic queries to test your page in the most accessible way.
After selecting an element, you can use the
to fire events and simulate user interactions with the page, or use Jest and
to make assertions about the element.
There are Testing Library helper methods that work with queries. As elements appear and disappear in response to actions,
can be used to await the changes in the DOM. To find only elements that are children of a specific element, you can use
. If necessary, there are also a few options you can
, like the timeout for retries and the default testID attribute.
: Returns the matching node for a query, and throw a descriptive error if no elements match
if more than one match is found (use
instead if more than one element is expected).
: Returns the matching node for a query, and return
if no elements match. This is useful for asserting an element that is not present. Throws an error if more than one match is found (use

: Returns a Promise which resolves when an element is found which matches the given query. The promise is rejected if no element is found or if more than one element is found after a default timeout of 1000ms. If you need to find more than one element, use
: Returns an array of all matching nodes for a query, and throws an error if no elements match.
: Returns an array of all matching nodes for a query, and return an empty array (
: Returns a promise which resolves to an array of elements when any elements are found which match the given query. The promise is rejected if no elements are found after a default timeout of
, your test should resemble how users interact with your code (component, page, etc.) as much as possible. With this in mind, we recommend this order of priority:
Queries that reflect the experience of visual/mouse users as well as those that use assistive technology.
: This can be used to query every element that is exposed in the
option you can filter the returned elements by their
. This should be your top preference for just about everything. There's not much you can't get with this (if you can't, it's possible your UI is inaccessible). Most often, this will be used with the
: This method is really good for form fields. When navigating through a website form, users find elements using label text. This method emulates that behavior, so it should be your top preference.
A placeholder is not a substitute for a label
. But if that's all you have, then it's better than alternatives.
: Outside of forms, text content is the main way users find elements. This method can be used to find non-interactive elements (like divs, spans, and paragraphs).
: The current value of a form element can be useful when navigating a page with filled-in values.
HTML5 and ARIA compliant selectors. Note that the user experience of interacting with these attributes varies greatly across browsers and assistive technology.
: If your element is one which supports
, and any custom element), then you can use this to find that element.
: The title attribute is not consistently read by screenreaders, and is not visible by default for sighted users
: The user cannot see (or hear) these, so this is only recommended for cases where you can't match by role or text or it doesn't make sense (e.g. the text is dynamic).
The base queries from DOM Testing Library require you to pass a
as the first argument. Most framework-implementations of Testing Library provide a pre-bound version of these queries when you render your components with them which means you
do not have to provide a container
. In addition, if you just want to query
The primary argument to a query can be a
. There are also options to adjust how node text is parsed. See
for documentation on what can be passed to a query.

Most of the query APIs take a
as an argument, which means the argument can be either a
also accept an object as the final argument that can contain options that affect the precision of string matching:
; matches full strings, case-sensitive. When false, matches substrings and is not case-sensitive.
In most cases using a regex instead of a string gives you more control over fuzzy matching and should be preferred over
: An optional function which overrides normalization behavior. See
Before running any matching logic against text in the DOM,

automatically normalizes that text. By default, normalization consists of trimming whitespace from the start and end of text, and collapsing multiple adjacent whitespace characters into a single space.
If you want to prevent that normalization, or provide alternative normalization (e.g. to remove Unicode control characters), you can provide a
function in the options object. This function will be given a string and is expected to return a normalized version of that string.
the built-in normalization, but you can call
to obtain a built-in normalizer, either to adjust that normalization or to call it from your own normalizer.
takes an options object which allows the selection of behaviour:
. Collapses inner whitespace (newlines, tabs, repeated spaces) into a single space.
To perform a match against text without trimming:
To override normalization to remove some Unicode characters whilst keeping some (but not all) of the built-in normalization behavior:
For convenience screen also exposes a
method in addition to the queries. This method is essentially a shortcut for
. It supports debugging the document, a single element, or an array of elements.
, screen exposes this convenient method which logs a URL that can be opened in a browser.
On top of the queries provided by the testing library, you can use the regular

to query elements. Note that using this as an escape hatch to query by class or id is not recommended because they are invisible to the user. Use a testid if you have to, to make your intention to fall back to non-semantic queries clear and establish a stable API contract in the HTML.
Do you still have problems knowing how to use Testing Library queries?
There is a very cool Browser extension for

named Testing Playground, and it helps you find the best queries to select elements. It allows you to inspect the element hierarchies in the Browser's Developer Tools, and provides you with suggestions on how to select them, while encouraging good testing practices.
If you want to get more familiar with these queries, you can try them out on
. Testing Playground is an interactive sandbox where you can run different queries against your own html, and get visual feedback matching the rules mentioned above.
Most projects have a few use cases for
, but the majority of the time you should probably use
// <button>Submit</button>fireEvent(  getByText(container, 'Submit'),  new MouseEvent('click', {    bubbles: true,    cancelable: true,  }),)

This is particularly useful for a change event:
property that contains data transferred during the operation. As a convenience, if you provide a

This should predominantly be used for testing drag and drop interactions.
